	=95 Frontier report
15179 queues: 191 active (50 in-process; 31 ready; 110=
 snoozed); 78  
inactive; 0 retired; 14910 exhausted

On Feb 3, 2010, at 10=
:55 AM, Gordon Mohr wrote:

> Derek Pappas wrote (offlist, but was OK with =
an on-list reply):
>> Gordon,
>>
>> You may or may not be interested to see=
 what the Hertrix traffic  
>> pattern
>> looks like over a two week period=
.
>> All four crawlers were restarted two weeks ago.
>>
>> There are 4 comp=
uters running crawlers and the traffic pattern slows
>> over time even thou=
gh the queue size is increasing.
> [screenshot of H1 console and of bandwid=
th graph was attached]
>
> It's normal for the rate to slow, for a variety =
of different reasons.
> But that rate (<10 URI/sec) is suspiciously slow fo=
r having so many
> independent queues to crawl (load factor 16+), and all t=
hreads (50)  
> active.
>
> What's the hardware like?
>
> Might the machine=
 be swapping?
>
> Are there other busy/memory-intensive processes active on=
 the same  
> machine?
>
> Could a majority of the sites targeted by live q=
ueues be not  
> responding
> to your connect requests, and thus encounteri=
ng both slow (20-30  
> second)
> socket timeouts, and slow (15 minute) ret=
ry cycles? This could be the
> case if sites have explicitly blocked your I=
P, or if you've hit a  
> large
> collection of related trap sites (such as=
 wildcard subdomains) that  
> are
> all unresponsive/intentionally-slow. T=
he frontier report provides the
> best clues if this is happening.
>
> Also=
, the 'out' bandwidth is *so* smooth for long periods that there
> could be=
 a cap or other traffic shaping on some overburdened link
> between the mac=
hine and the net.
>
> - Gordon
